Some time ago, there was a website that talked about the dangers of public check-ins. It said that if you put your location online, people you don't know can see it. This made people realize that there are some downsides to sharing everything on the internet.
The internet has a lot of opportunities for people to share their lives. You can write a blog, post photos, and share your thoughts with the world. But you should be careful about what you share online. If you put your personal information on the internet, people might be able to find it and use it against you.
There are some people who have learned from the mistakes of others. Heather Armstrong is one of them. She had a blog where she wrote about her life. One day, someone sent the address of her blog to her boss. As a result, she lost her job. But Armstrong didn't give up. She started a new blog and wrote about her family. Today, she is a successful blogger and her writing supports her family.

A long time ago, some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a movie called What the Bleep Do We Know. The movie showed that there is a lot about the universe that we don't understand. Some scientists felt that the movie was dangerous and issued warnings about it. The movie was very popular, but I couldn't see what all the fuss was about at first. However, when the movie moved on to describe some of the new discoveries, I started to see what the fuss was really about. One of the discoveries was that water molecules can be affected by thoughts. I had heard rumours about this before, but the movie gave me some evidence to support it. The evidence was not very convincing, but it was still enough to make me believe that the discovery was real. The movie also talked about other discoveries, such as the discovery of the universe being made from an unknown form of matter and the discovery that our conscious perception of events lags behind reality. These discoveries are amazing, but they also make me feel like we are further away from understanding the universe than ever before.

Writing novels is like planting a forest, and writing short stories is more like planting a garden. The two processes complement each other, creating a complete landscape. Writing novels takes a long time and a lot of commitment, while writing short stories is quicker and easier to complete. You can create a story out of the smallest things, and you don’t have to worry about failing. Short stories are like guideposts to your heart, and it makes you happy as a writer to be able to share these intimate feelings with your readers.

Science is a powerful force that has improved our lives and threatened our existence. It has also inspired us to dream big and to understand the universe. Science has its beauty and its perils, but it is also important and fallible.
Scientists come in many different colors, and they often disagree with each other. But they always keep working to learn new things and to improve their theories. Sometimes, scientists make big changes to their theories that can have a big impact on the world.
Science has also been used to control nature. We have moved from being simply observers of nature to being, in a modest but growing way, its controllers. Concomitantly, we have occasionally disturbed the balance of nature in ways that we did not always understand.
Science has become part of the human race’s way of conceiving of and manipulating its future. The manipulation of the future is not a question to be left to philosophers. The answers can affect the national budget, the health of your next child – even the long-term prospects for life on this planet.

From around 2015, major publishers started to notice that sales of ebooks had stopped growing, or even fallen in some cases. This made people question whether ebooks would continue to be popular. One publishing executive admitted that the ebooks hype may have been too much, and that his company had lost confidence in the power of the printed word. Despite the evidence, the idea that ebooks will 'kill' print books continues to be discussed. It is important to remember that digital and print books can coexist in the market. The potential disappearance of the book does not mean that it will cease to inspire us or provoke intense debate.
The idea of one medium 'killing' another has been used to describe many new technologies. Even before the invention of digital technologies, people predicted that existing media would die. But new technologies have often found new uses and survived. The same is true for books. As technology changes, we find ourselves longing for what we used to know, but no longer have. This is why entire industries develop around retro products and older technologies.

Every day, I wake up early to write about how some of the greatest minds of the past have approached their work. I write about their daily routines and how they made the time to do their best work. I also write about my own struggles with creativity and productivity.
I have a lot of concerns about creativity and productivity. How do you do meaningful creative work while also earning a living? Is it better to devote yourself wholly to a project or to set aside a small portion of each day? And when there doesn’t seem to be enough time for all you hope to accomplish, must you give things up or can you learn to condense activities, to do more in less time, to ‘work smarter, not harder’?
I have tried to provide examples of how a variety of brilliant and successful people have confronted many of the same challenges. I wanted to show how grand creative visions translate to small daily increments; how one’s working habits influence the work itself, and vice versa.
This book is about people’s routines. It’s about the circumstances of creative activity, not the product; it deals with manufacturing rather than meaning. But it’s also, inevitably, personal. I have documented all of my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also serve as a guide to further reading.

Howard became a palaeontologist because he was interested in dinosaurs. He wanted to become a palaeontologist since he was young. He studied delicate creatures revealed on the surface of grey rocks. He worked on his doctoral thesis and got a job as an Assistant Lecturer at Tavistock College in London. He was surprised at the evident favouritism from a man he did not know. But he was grateful that he had the job and could support himself by doing the sort of work he wanted to do.

Charles Spence is a Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. He has studied how the senses interact to form our perception of flavour. Through his studies, he has influenced what we eat and drink. He has also studied how the environment affects taste.
Spence has written a book called The Perfect Meal, which is packed with insights about food and drink. It is a fascinating book for anyone who loves to eat and drink.
Spence's lab is not very high-tech. It has soundproof booths and stacks of ancient-looking audio-visual equipment. He can afford to work more creatively with cooks because he keeps his overheads low.
Spence has been helping famous brands reduce salt and sugar in their products. He says that it is in their interests to help loyal customers stay alive for longer.
Spence has also studied the effects of sound on flavour. He has found that higher-pitched music enhances sweetness, and lower-pitched and brassy sounds make food taste bitter.

Our brains are very busy these days. We have a lot of information to deal with, including facts, rumors, and things that are not true. We also do more things ourselves now than we used to. For example, we make our own reservations and find things in shops. We do a lot of different things at once, but it's not always easy to keep up with everything. Our smartphones help us do all of this, but they also make it harder to focus.
When we think we're multitasking, we're actually switching from one task to another very quickly. This is not very efficient. Multitasking can also make us feel stressed and anxious. It can also make it harder to learn new information. If you do your homework and watch TV at the same time, the information from your schoolwork will not go to the right part of your brain.
Multitasking also requires a lot of decision-making. This can be very tiring for our brains. If we make a lot of small decisions, we can end up making a big decision that is not very well thought out. This is because our brains are not wired to multitask well. We are more like amateur plate spinners, frantically switching from one task to another, ignoring the one that’s not right in front of us but worried it’ll come crashing down any minute.

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino would break up concrete into pieces at night and throw them at visitors during the day. Was he being spiteful? In caves in the US, female bats help unrelated fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right birthing position. Are they being caring? Fifty years ago, people thought that animals didn’t have consciousness, feelings or moral systems. But recently that has changed. Thanks to research into the behaviour of bats, chimps, and other animals, emotions of animals have gone from being a taboo area of investigation to being tentatively explored. It is a change that has in recent years filtered through the scientific strata to a selection of popular science books. And it has started a debate that may never be solved: can animals be said to have consciousness?
The debate about animal consciousness raises a second question: conscience – a person’s moral sense of right and wrong that guides their behaviour. In a recent experiment, it became apparent that cows that successfully opened the gate themselves showed more pleasure than those that had to have the gate opened for them. If, as this research seems to imply, cows enjoy problem-solving, what does it mean for the production and consumption of beef? The observations may not be disputed, but the interpretation of them is. Some people believe that the only logically consistent response to the new research is to stop eating meat. Others believe that we should at the very least re-evaluate our view of animal cognition. Still others believe that we should just stop anthropomorphising animals. The debate may never be solved because it is a philosophical one.

Critical thinking is a way of understanding things more deeply. It involves interacting with what we read or listen to in a way that helps us to think more deeply.
There is a belief that argument is a way of finding the truth. Although technology can help us store and process information, it can also make it more difficult to think critically.
One problem is that technology can make it easier to get information quickly, but it can also make it harder to reflect on that information. This is because many visual media are real-time media that do not allow time for reflection, analysis, or imagination.
Another problem is that technology can make it easier to become distracted. This is because there are many distractions on the internet and on our phones.
Despite these challenges, there are some ways to use technology to improve your critical thinking skills. For example, you can read books, articles, and blogs on a variety of topics. You can also use technology to find information and to connect with others who are interested in the same topics.

When Matthew Crawford is not writing or thinking about how we should live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He wrote two books about the benefits of manual trades and how to cope with modernity.
Crawford says that our attention is being pulled away by many things, such as advertisements and video games. It is becoming more and more difficult to think or remember conversations we’ve had. And because everyone is trying to protect themselves from being interrupted, we close ourselves off and no longer want to do simple things like chat to strangers.
Crawford's proposed solution has two parts. First, we need regulation of noise and distraction in public space. More importantly, though, Crawford advocates skilled practices as a way of engaging with the world in a more satisfying way.
For example, if you like to cook, you can practice your skills by making a meal for your family and friends. If you like to play hockey, you can practice your skills by playing with your friends. If you like to ride motorcycles, you can practice your skills by riding with your friends.

"What do you do for a living?" is a common question that people often ask. If you are a philosopher, it can be a little harder to answer this question. This is because describing yourself as a philosopher sounds a bit pretentious. However, there are some good reasons why philosophers are important.
One reason is that philosophers have established themselves as people who judge the activities of others and celebrate intellectual life. They have also argued that a life lived in contemplation, i.e. a philosophical life, is the most virtuous of all.
Another reason is that philosophy can help people look a little more closely at the practices and behaviours that define their lives. It can help people to understand themselves better and to make better decisions.
If you are interested in learning more about philosophy, there are many resources available to you. You can read books, articles, and blogs about philosophy. You can also find online courses and lectures.

Foodies, gourmands, chefs and others who love food might expect that thinking critically about what and how we eat can contribute to culinary pleasure. However, historically, philosophical discussions about food have been mostly about other topics, such as the acquisition of knowledge. Sometimes, philosophical conversations about food appear to be about other things, but when you look closer, you find that they are actually about something else. It is interesting to note the case of the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus, who believed that the pursuit of pleasure and the avoidance of pain should be the goal of life. Epicurus' name is often used to describe people who love to eat and drink. Restaurants, food shops and online recipe sites often use the name Epicurus to promote their products. These businesses expect that if their products are seen to be approved by eminent philosophers, they will be more successful. Food is also social and cultural. It is shared with family, friends and the community. It brings people together and helps them to build relationships. Food is also a topic of ethical debate. We can ask questions about what we should eat and why. There are also ethical issues related to cooking in restaurants and at home. Finally, food can be used to bridge cultural gaps. It can help us to appreciate others and forge personal bonds with people from other cultures.

Rob Daviau is a designer from the US who creates legacy board games. These games are different from traditional board games because they have a permanent impact on the game. For example, in one game, you might have to rip up cards or deface the board. The games play out over a fixed number of sessions and long-held grudges become woven into the fabric of the game.
Daviau was asked to collaborate on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular co-operative board game. His next project was a board game called SeaFall. Legacy board game designers must consider all possible player choices to ensure the narrative doesn’t fall apart. To do this, designers recruit testers so they can observe how board games will unfold.
Legacy board games were never expected to go mainstream, but most players love the concept. The appeal of an unfolding adventure trumped any concerns about longevity. The legacy format draws on video games and the demand for episodic entertainment fuelled by popular TV series.

Once upon a time, there was an octopus named Inky who lived in a tank at the New Zealand National Aquarium. One night, Inky managed to escape from his tank and swim across the floor to a drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. It was a story that was shared online and was very popular.
One of the reasons why people find stories like Inky's so interesting is because they involve anthropomorphism, which means treating animals like humans. In the case of octopuses, this pleasure is especially pronounced because of their intelligence and their bodies that are very different from our own.
Animals have been observed exhibiting many of the same behaviors that humans can do, such as considering the past and the future, demonstrating empathy, and being self-aware. However, there are some things that humans can do that animals cannot, such as fully-developed language.
It is important to remember that animals are not exactly like humans. They have their own unique ways of thinking and behaving. For example, squirrels are not very good at remembering human memory tasks, but they are very good at remembering where they have hidden their nuts. And octopuses are not very good at producing color patterns, but they are very good at squeezing through narrow drains.

Once upon a time, there was a technology called robotics that has the potential to change the world. Robots have already been used in factories and cars for many years, but now they are starting to be used in many other places too.
One of the biggest problems with robotics is that it can lead to job loss. Many people believe that robots will take over their jobs, but this is not necessarily true. While it is true that robots can do some things that humans can do, they cannot do everything. This means that there will still be plenty of jobs for humans in the future.
Another problem with robotics is that it can lead to safety risks. For example, robots can be dangerous to work around, and they can also cause accidents. It is important to develop new regulations to ensure that robots are safe and that they do not harm people.
Despite the challenges, robotics has the potential to improve our lives in many ways. For example, robots can help us to do things that are currently difficult or impossible. They can also help us to live longer and healthier lives.
In order to prepare for the robotic workforce of tomorrow, we need to invest in education and training programs. We also need to develop new regulatory frameworks to ensure that robots are safe and that they do not harm people.

The mountaineer George Mallory said that he climbed Mount Everest because it was there. Many people wonder why people climb mountains. It is possible that the climber’s answer may inspire some to act on their dreams. Climbing can give people a feeling of freedom, but it can also be very confining. There is an apparent paradox in many forms of climbing. However, climbing can also help cultivate important virtues such as courage, humility and respect for the environment.
When asked why he climbed, US rock climber Joe Fitschen said that a better question would be 'Why do people climb?' Climbing is in our genes and it is inherent in our basic makeup to take on challenges and test limits. Climbing can also help develop important virtues such as courage, humility and respect for the environment.

Alfred Brendel is a famous pianist who has been playing classical music for many years. He is known for his intellectual and disciplined personality. Brendel has written and played a lot of music, but he has not taught very many students. Those who knew him well saw a playful side to his character, but that was seldom on display in his concerts.
Brendel has a young student named Kit Armstrong. Kit is a talented musician who is learning from Brendel. Kit is a restless and impatient young man who is always learning new things. He is also a composer. Brendel is impressed by Kit's ability to listen to his own playing and his sensitivity to sound.
Brendel is now 80 years old and he is still playing music. He is proud of his accomplishments and he is excited about his future.

My grandparents' garden was a beautiful place. It was on the bank of a river and sloped gently down towards the water. You couldn't reach the river but you could hear the sound of the water and the birds that sang in the trees above. I imagined that all gardens were like this – a place of escape, peace and solitude.
My father was a quiet and withdrawn person. He had a lot of phrases that he liked to use, one of them being 'It's immaterial to me'. He was probably disappointed that he hadn't made more of his life. He left school without qualifications and became apprenticed to a plumber. It wasn't something he was passionate about.
I always wanted to like the piano but it did its best to intimidate me. The only thing I did like about it were the two brass candlesticks that jutted out from the front. I'd walk along the river bank looking for a suitable spot where I could take off the painful sandals and leave them with my picnic while I ventured out, tentatively, peering through the water for any fish that I could scoop up with the net and take home.
One day my father announced that there was a vacancy for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested. I like to feel that somewhere deep down inside him, although he hated gardening himself, he'd watched me doing it for long enough and noticed the keenness and the passion for all things that grew and flowered and fruited that hadn't disappeared.

Lawrence MacEwen lives on the Isle of Muck, a small island in Scotland. The island is surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean. There is a strong wind blowing today, and it can make it dangerous to be near the cliff. MacEwen's sheepdog, Tie, is playing with the sheep. The wind is very strong, but MacEwen is not worried. He is happy to be on his island.
MacEwen is giving me a tour of his neighbourhood. He points to the different islands and tells me about them. He also tells me about the history of his island. The island has been inhabited by the MacEwen family for many years.
MacEwen has a lot of responsibilities on his island. He runs the farm, the cottages, and the hotel. He also takes care of the sheep. One day, there is a problem with Tie. He is not circling the sheep properly. MacEwen is disappointed, but he doesn't give up. He tries to fix the problem.
The Isle of Muck is a beautiful island. It is a peaceful place to live. But it also has its challenges. One challenge is the lack of electricity. Another challenge is the lack of mobile phone service. However, MacEwen is able to cope with these challenges. He is happy to be living on his island.

The game design industry is a competitive one, but it is also expanding. To get into the industry, you need to have a passion for games and be willing to work hard. You can start by making games on your own, or you can take a postgraduate course in games. If you want to work for a big company, you will need to have a degree in computer science. However, if you are not interested in working for a big company, you can still get involved in the industry by creating your own games or working as an artist or programmer.

Since I was young, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, and I'm grateful that he didn't push me too much. I had a friend who was also passionate about football, but he stopped playing and hasn't been involved in the sport since. I'm glad that I didn't have that happen to me. When I score a goal, people often say that it's just luck, but it isn't. I have worked hard to improve my skills since I was a child. If I'm teaching kids, the most important thing I try to get across is to enjoy learning skills. I used to do many different sports at school, but football was the only thing I was really passionate about. I want to make sure that my son has the same opportunities that I had. I'm not rich, but I have a lot of friends and family who support me. I also like to help others. After I stop playing football, I think I'll have a year off or perhaps even longer, doing the things I haven't been able to do all these years.

It was because of Sam Carter that we lived at Reef Point. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He found a cheap place for us to live. Los Angeles was not a very pleasant place to live. It was very hot and there was a lot of sea fog. Reef Point was not very popular with day trippers. The road was uninviting and there was a charming little resort nearby. If you were broke or surfing mad, you would risk the last mile. But now, with the hot weather, the place was busy. My father was working hard to write a script. I spent a lot of time on the beach reading books and playing with my dog, Rusty. Rusty was a very friendly dog. He loved the beach and he always wanted to swim. Sometimes he would dig up things that were not his. I had to return those things to their owners. One day, we went swimming. My father drove to Los Angeles to deliver the script. Rusty and I spent a lot of time swimming in the sea. The sun was setting and it was getting cooler. We sat watching the surfers. They were very busy surfing all day. One surfer caught my eye. She had a style that made all the others look like clumsy amateurs. But now she seemed to decide to call it a day and rode in on a final wave.

The boat was crowded with people waiting to board. There were long lines of people waiting to get on. It was not a good day to travel. There was a problem with the computer system. The atmosphere became dark and people started to get angry. Violet was feeling frustrated. She had lost her phone and she couldn't call anyone. She was also worried about her neighbor, Kristina, who had no other way to find her numbers. But eventually, the lines started to move forward and Violet was able to get to her room. She was happy to have her own balcony.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he discovered the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for images to use in a book about the history of the Portage Park neighbourhood in Chicago. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Maier, a street photographer with a keen eye for capturing compelling images. Since then, Maloof has amassed an archive of Maier’s life and work. He has a lot of her cameras, film, prints, negatives, movies and audiotapes.
Maier was born in 1926 and spent much of her childhood in France. She returned to New York in 1951 and came to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier always had a camera with her and dressed in oversized coats, broad-brimmed hats and stout shoes. She was a private person but had strong opinions about movies and politics.
Maier’s work is the purest form of art. It was not done for any commercial reason. Her images lean toward women, children, the old, the poor, and the abstract. Maloof often wonders if he’ll ever work his way through all the negatives. He had no real interest in photography until he discovered Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural shots, Maloof actually went out on the street and began to take his own pictures.

When a novel is described as ambitious, it usually means that it is not very successful. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. The book is set in New Zealand during the 1860s and is a murder mystery. The plot is complex and there are many characters. Catton said she set out to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past offered more opportunities for complications and misunderstandings for her characters to deal with. The book is long, but Catton said she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters ‘a decent show’. The book is also exciting and fun to read. Catton is a talented writer and she has a lot of enthusiasm for her craft.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead loved to play the guitar. He learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven and wanted to learn the bass guitar when he was sixteen. He studied guitars and figured out how different shapes and types of wood affected the sound. He also learned how to build his own instruments.
Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, but he didn’t think of it as a career. He was also into painting and sculpture. He chose to study architecture at university but dropped out because he was too individualistic. He then decided to focus on his passion for sculpture and guitar-building.
Ever since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. He has to make a living by making a limited number of guitars each year. But he is still passionate about his work and believes that developing a career is more straightforward today.

When two English people meet, they often talk about the weather. This is because the English have a special way of talking about the weather that is like a code. It is called 'weather-speak.'
Weather-speak is used in three specific contexts. First, it can be used as a simple greeting. Second, it can be used as an ice-breaker to start a conversation. Third, it can be used as a filler topic when there is a pause or uncomfortable silence.
When people talk about the weather in England, they are not necessarily talking about the actual weather. They are using weather-speak as a way to start a conversation and to make people feel comfortable.

Alice Leader was standing in front of the remains of a Roman wall in Britain. She was explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds about the amazing engineering feat it was to build something so long and tall. She had already excited her students about the trip, but they really wanted to know why it was built. Alice felt her answers were not satisfactory. She decided to write her own novel to add context and human interest to life at the Wall in Roman times. After retiring from teaching, Alice started writing her first novel in 2001. She was inspired to write because there was a gap in the market for children's fiction. She also felt that writing was more exciting and less exhausting than teaching. With the help of her husband, Alice was able to edit and publish her novel.

To raise money for charity, two brothers, Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, were challenged to take part in a unique race. The race was held in the wild and mountainous Yorkshire Dales of northern England.
Jonny raced in a car on the roads, while Alistair raced across the country on a mountain bike. The race started at a beautiful lake and finished at the highest road in Yorkshire.
There were some obstacles in the race. The first obstacle was a giant tractor that lumbered out of a field and onto the road. The second obstacle was the slope of the hill that forced Alistair to dismount his bike and carry it up.
Despite the obstacles, both brothers finished the race. They were both exhausted, but they were happy that they had completed the challenge.

The silence at Centre Court during the Wimbledon tennis championships is very quiet. You can bounce the ball, serve, and hit it, and you hear the echo of your own shot. The grass is soft and the stadium is ancient. The players wear white and the crowds are respectful. The quiet of the Centre Court is good for your game. It helps you to focus on the point you are playing and to shut everything else out.
When a point is done, there is a lot of noise. People cheer and applaud. You hear them, but it feels like they are coming from a long way away. You are so focused on the game that you don't notice the number of people watching you.
I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. I had played there before, but I had never won. In 2008, I was playing in the final again. I was confident that I had learned from my defeat in 2007 and that I would win.

In the early 1950s, a young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. She spent most of her life in Africa and became known for her work as a scientist, activist, and environmentalist.
Goodall's research on chimpanzees has been very influential. She discovered that chimpanzees eat meat, use tools, and have emotions like humans. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is a leading authority on chimpanzee research.
Goodall's work has also changed the way humans think about themselves. She has helped us to understand that we are more closely related to chimpanzees than we thought. She has also helped us to understand that we share many similarities with chimpanzees, such as our ability to learn and solve problems.
Even as a child, there were signs that Goodall would become a scientist. When she was five years old, she spent five hours hiding in a henhouse to learn how hens lay eggs. This event is a clear indicator of Goodall's curiosity and determination.

During my first conversation, Shirley Ford spoke to me in the voice of a young boy, his tired mother, and a fast-talking alien. Her voices are similar to those heard on children’s TV and cartoons, and to people who have seen computerised employee programmes about health and safety.
Shirley talked about what it takes to do voiceovers. You have to bring the script to life for an audience who can’t see you. You also have to be able to create the right sounds from the back of your throat.
After school, Shirley enrolled on a drama course and had some occasional work singing jingles for TV adverts. One day, she was asked to try out for the part of a rabbit in the soundtrack for a cartoon. Amazingly, she ended up getting a major part.
Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices as she watches children’s TV. The competition for work is fierce, and a good showreel is essential.
For anyone considering a career doing voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops’ and having a passion for human sound.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. It's a dream job that many people have. But most people eventually give up on their dreams and consider more realistic professions. To become a cartoonist, you don't need a lot of money or a university degree. You just need your brain, your hand, and something that makes a mark. If you feel that drawing is your passion and you're willing to work hard, you can make it as a cartoonist. You can learn a lot from doing different types of art and drawing. You can also learn from working with others. If you're interested in becoming a cartoonist, there are a few things you can do. First, draw a lot and practice your skills. Second, get involved in art clubs or organizations. Third, submit your work to local art competitions. Finally, don't be afraid to ask for feedback from experienced cartoonists.

Twenty years ago, I was moving house and had a lot of things to get rid of. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had bought me for my 16th birthday. I felt sad about throwing it away, but I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to put it on a pile of rubbish. Suddenly, a young man came up to me and asked if I was going to throw it away. I said yes and he asked if he could have it. I gave it to him and felt sad that I had thrown it away.
A few months later, I got an email from someone I didn't know. It was from a dealer and restorer of guitars called Keith Rushton. He said he had my guitar and offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy to get my guitar back and I started playing it again.
I had forgotten all about my dad's habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything I had, including my guitar. My dad had been very keen for me to learn the classical guitar, but I couldn't make much progress. So I switched to the electric guitar and started playing undemanding stuff.
Now that I'm learning it again, I guess I'll have to form a band. Maybe I can play with my son or there are other people of my age who have had a similar experience to mine. Maybe we could call ourselves 'The Regainers'!'

There has been a lot of talk about sleep lately. Sleep is very important for our mental, physical, and social well-being. It seems that people who have the hardest time sleeping appreciate how important sleep is the most.
When we wake up from sleep, we often forget our dreams. The dreams that we remember are usually the ones that occur during the REM stage of sleep. REM is the stage of sleep where we dream the most vividly.
Dreams are important for creativity. When people are awakened out of REM, they are able to think more creatively and flexibly. This is because dreams help us to find new patterns and create combinations that break through our usual habits of thinking.
So, everyone needs to dream. Whether you are a writer, artist, teacher, or politician, dreams can help you to think creatively and flexibly.

It was twenty years ago that Susie Ray left London for a small coastal town in south-west England. She has a studio with a beautiful sea view and hangs photographs of her two daughters on the walls. Susie is a copyist artist who can reproduce the richness of an early-20th-century impressionist masterpiece as easily as the brilliance of a 16th-century Caravaggio portrait.
The problem is that Susie is very popular. She has painted the works of numerous great artists, including Renoir, Monet and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so faithful that art experts mistake them for the originals.
Susie has always been open about what she does. When she reproduces an old masterpiece, she will make it look as authentic as possible. However, she will put her own signature on the back of the canvas.
When younger painters approach Susie for advice, she stresses the importance of learning to draw and to represent things accurately. She also emphasises how much she’s studied to be able to do what she does.

Ellen MacArthur was a racer who loved the sea. She had a special connection with her boats. They worked together like one. When she was on land, she felt like everything was trivial. After she won a race, she took you on a tour of her boat. She talked about the careful planning that went into provisioning and housekeeping. She said that preparation was everything. She also started a charity to help young people rethink and redesign a sustainable future.
The text has been simplified by removing unnecessary details and jargon, using simpler vocabulary and sentence structure, and breaking up the text into shorter paragraphs. The factual content of the original text has been preserved.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his generation. Young people are spending more time on computers and games consoles, so Jordan hopes to inspire kids to climb their own mountains or venture outdoors. His team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' If Jordan can climb Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will become the youngest person to have climbed the Seven Summits. Few people achieve this under the age of thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of the Seven Summits and might actually do it before his teenage years are over.
There are some concerns about Jordan's climb. Some people think that a young climber might not be emotionally strong enough or have enough experience. But Jordan's parents believe that their own experience as climbers will help them guide their son. They also think that watching Jordan develop gives them confidence.
Jordan's motivation is also a question. Some people might wonder if this is just an ambitious father taking his own love of adventure to a dangerous extreme. But Paul insists that this project isn't about him trying to become famous for his son's achievements. He says, 'If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he’s done with mountain climbing and wants to play basketball instead, we’ll shut this whole project down and go to the gym.'

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's probably not classical music they're listening to. Most people our age can name a lot of pop groups, but ask any of my friends if they know who Brahms was and they probably won't have a clue. I'm doing a music degree, but the people on my course know no more about classical music than anyone else my age. If you don't know who wrote the music, you are unlikely to own any recordings of their work. The statistics are not very encouraging for a lover of classical music. Apparently only a small number of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells very few copies. I still find that hard to believe. So, what has caused this decline in interest for classical music? Well, there are a few reasons. First of all, classical music is not very popular among teenagers. It's not the music that we like to listen to when we relax. In addition, the way we listen to music has changed. Nowadays, you can find any music you want at the click of a mouse, and the sound track to our lives is rarely classical.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mom's car and looked at Almonside School. It was a funny school with lots of buildings and trees. There was a riding centre where the horses were kept. Bonnie treated the horses with respect. She rode a horse named Maverick and had a lot of fun.
The riding centre was a nice old building with a large structure for indoor riding. There was a lot of equipment for riding horses. Bonnie put a saddle on Maverick's back and rode him around the paddock. She felt like a queen on a horse. She went round and round the paddock and had a lot of fun.

I met Cody Simpson a long time ago. He is a young Australian singer who has released many successful songs. He started singing when he was very young. One day, he posted some videos of himself singing on the internet. These videos became popular and people started asking for more. Cody was happy to oblige. He started recording more videos and people loved them.
But Cody was also a very talented swimmer. He was training hard and had a lot of success. However, record labels came calling and offered him a deal to move to the US and become a singer. Cody had to make a difficult decision. He had to choose between his dream of becoming a swimmer and his dream of becoming a singer.
In the end, Cody decided to take the chance and move to the US. He has been very successful as a singer. He has traveled to many countries and played in front of thousands of fans. However, Cody knows that his success will not last forever. He is grateful for his family and friends who have supported him through his journey.

I woke up early and looked at the river. The ice was shining in the sunlight. I helped my family to protect the buildings from flooding. I worked hard all last week. My grandfather didn’t notice. I saw a boy on the river bank. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf. I was going kayaking. I put on my wetsuit and jacket. I checked my lucky chain. It was a silver chain that my grandfather brought back from South America. I went to the kitchen and ate breakfast. My mom smiled at me. She said I was up early for a Saturday. I headed down the hallway and saw Grandpa. He was angry. He said I didn’t win the competition. I felt sad, but I didn’t let him get to me. I went outside and went to the boathouse.

**
Mum caught Jess by the arm and asked her to come with her to the study. There was a painting on the table. It was one of Grandpa's, but it was different from his other paintings. It was not finished and it was strange. There was a river in the painting. It was not a real river, it was a fantasy river. The picture was beautiful, but it was also mysterious. There were no animals or people in the painting. It felt like there was no place for living things. But Jess was captivated by the painting. She thought about the coming of autumn after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. She said the painting had a name. It was called 'River Boy'. The name was important to Jess. She didn't know why, but it was. And there was another mystery. The painting was not finished. Maybe Grandpa was going to put the boy in later.

When I woke up this morning, I didn't mean to damage my bedroom carpet. It just seemed like a good idea at the time. I was trying to find a way of fitting my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran had given me the cabinet when she moved out of her house into a flat. It's really cute. I keep my collection of shells and fossils and interesting stones there.
The problem was, the cabinet was too tall. If I could only slice a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it... That was when it came to me. If I couldn't slice anything off Gran’s cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It just seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I reckoned he would be quite pleased with me.

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They borrow things from the normal-sized people in order to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of the novel, I knew it was going to be hard to live up to people’s expectations. The author had told me she wanted the series to be from the Borrowers' perspective, not a human one, which made filming much more complex.
The most crucial thing was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so I had to be much further away from the camera than on a normal shoot. When filming the human surroundings the Borrowers found themselves in, the crew had to crawl along the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimetres, in order to get the Borrowers' perspective.
One big challenge was finding a way to get the shadows right when the images of the supposedly tiny Borrowers were combined with a background image of ordinary-sized surroundings. We developed a unique technique for this. The costumes were also a big challenge. They had to be made out of heavy canvas material so that they stuck out in the way that dolls’ clothes do. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think either of them thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes!

Mom pulled up at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looked around nervously, but there were no journalists there. I was excited to see how long it would take before the craziness began. It always does. The fake smiles, the wannabe friends, the people who want free tickets to one of my dad’s concerts. I told her, "Everything’s going to be fine." She kissed her fingertip and touched my cheek right before I got out of the car. Then she was off, leaving me alone with this whole new school and situation to deal with. But this is what I asked her for. To get away from my old life on the road and tour tutors. So while the rest of the band is renting here during the recording, we’re staying for good. I wanted to meet real kids for a change. How about a kid with a mom who types from nine to five in an office? Or a dad who cuts grass? That’d be so cool. So normal. I walked into the school’s main office and asked for my schedule. The secretary seemed confused. But I got my schedule and it was cool. English Literature, first period. I was late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map the night before, as I didn’t want to look like a complete buffoon searching for my classes. When I got to the door, I heard the teacher already taking roll. I slipped in undetected and slid into the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiled. She was friendly. 'Nice shoes,' she whispered. I knew I should have worn sneakers. 'Thanks,' I said. The teacher paused in the roll taking. 'Desert... McGraw?' she said hesitantly. 'Here.' The teacher then smiled and introduced herself as Ms. Smigla. She talked a lot and eventually handed us our course outlines. After we reviewed them and she told us all about books we’re required to read this year, she actually gave us time to socialize! All teachers should realize the importance of this.

In the United States, teenage girls are expected to be Student Council presidents and have part-time jobs, volunteer, and excel in all of these fields. It's what being an American teenager is like today. Teenage boys and girls have a lot of responsibilities, including homework, tests, extra-curricular activities, jobs, chores, and family obligations. They also have to deal with the stress of trying to maintain a social life.
There are some negative stereotypes about teenagers, such as being lazy, disrespectful, and rebellious. However, not everyone agrees with these stereotypes. Some people believe that teenagers are actually hard-working and ambitious. They also point out that teenagers have a lot of homework and other responsibilities, so it's not surprising that they need to use their cell phones a lot.
Teenagers today have a lot of challenges, but they also have a lot of opportunities. They can take their work on the go with them and do their homework wherever they are. They can also use their cell phones to connect with friends and family.
In the future, it's likely that the stereotype of teenagers will change. However, one thing is for sure, teenagers will continue to prove that they are capable of great things.

The Earth to Sky Calculus Club is a group of teenagers who live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness. They have launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space. It's a long-running science project that includes astronomy experiments and backcountry adventures.
One weekend, I joined the club to release a high-altitude balloon. We inflated the balloon and watched it rise into the sky. We also watched shooting stars. After the launch, some of the students stayed to watch the stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and gazed at the sky.
It took us a long time to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a cascading waterfall. The camera hadn't recorded any shooting stars. But it was still a great adventure.

Chloe Morgan loves science, especially Palaeontology. She started to be interested in the subject when she was fifteen. It happened by chance when her younger brother was going through the dinosaur phase. Chloe was reluctant to help at first, but she ended up lending him a hand with a science project. She also found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology that blew her mind. She knew that this was something she wanted to commit herself to.
Paleontology is not a common career choice for young people, but Chloe was determined to make it her dream. She met her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was famous already. He was approachable and easy-going, and he showed her a lot of patience.
Dinosaurs continue to fascinate us because they speak to the innate explorer in all of us. They are mysterious and unknown, and they offer the promise of discovery. Palaeontology is a great form of time travel.

When you travel by car with your family, even when you're young, you probably know that you're not 'there yet,' even when you ask over and over 'Are we there yet?' It's not 'there' anymore once you get there. It's 'here'. If you really think there's a chance that you're 'there' yet, you should be asking 'Are we here yet?'. And I'm sure there's no one who wishes they were 'there yet' more than the mums and dads fielding that question over and over every single long car trip.
When you travel by car, you can have a lot of fun. You can watch DVDs, listen to music, and play puzzles. You can also act as co-pilot and help your parents keep the car running smoothly. But sometimes, things can go wrong. For example, your brother or sister might put their foot on your side of the seat or hurl their whole body over into your space. If this happens, you might get angry and start fighting. But don't worry, your parents will probably be there to help you calm down.
Over the years, your dad has developed some strategies for dealing with kids on the back seat. One of his strategies is to say, 'Yup. We're here. Get out of the car.' This usually keeps everyone quiet for a while. You know that you're finally 'there' when you see the grown-ups tumble out of the car and go as far away as they can from the kids.

John and Zuzi Morgan have a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They decided to turn their love of tabletop games into a full-time business because there is so much technology and people are busy on their mobile phones and gadgets. The games that are played in their café are called Eurogames. They are known for their gentle themes and easy rules.
One of the most successful Eurogames is Pandemic. It was created by Matt Leacock, a North American designer. He was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. Pandemic is a cooperative game where players work together to solve global problems.
The growth of the video games industry has also helped to the success of Eurogames. Video games have become more popular than ever before, and this has led to more people being open to playing board games. As a result, tabletop gaming has become more popular than ever before.

**
Jamie Scott is a musician who has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits of recent years. He says his mom was a great singer and that she got him started on the guitar. He started playing music when he was 12 years old and he had to choose between tennis and music. He decided to focus on music because it was his passion. At 17, he left school to try to make it as a performer. He was part of a duo with a friend, but they had to split up because the record labels were only interested in him as a solo act. After a few near misses, he was signed to a music publisher and released a new album. However, fame and fortune did not follow. He had to ask the record label to let him go and switch to another label to release a new album. Writing for others is where he was to really find his feet. He has helped many artists to write songs that have gone to number one.

**
Tony Connor is a famous person who does stunts on bikes. He is called a 'street trials cyclist'. He jumps from tall places and lands safely in other strange places. His stunts are filmed and posted online.
One Saturday morning, Tony met with me in a BMX park. The local boys all knew exactly who he was. Many older people came to pay their respects to him. Tony is very brave and imaginative. He is willing to take risks.
However, Tony is not always happy. He says that he finds the social side of being famous difficult. He prefers to do his own thing rather than talk to people.
Despite his fame, Tony is grateful for the opportunity to make a living through his videos. He says that the technology gives people like him the chance to make a living.
Tony's story is an example of how someone can overcome fear and achieve their goals. He is a role model for people of all ages.

**
Television presenter Helen Skelton has completed many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a desert marathon and journeyed down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, a long thin piece of metal, high above the ground. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist attached to another wire above. To help her keep her balance and not to fall, she carried a long stick. Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. Although she already had a few circus skills, she quickly discovered that high-wire walking was completely different. The training was hard. Every day started early and there was a lot of exercise. But Helen was determined to complete the challenge. The day of the actual challenge was windy. The walk took a long time, but Helen was able to complete it. She was glad that it was over.

**
In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, a very old-fashioned bicycle. He had already written a book about his experiences travelling around Canada in a very old car and was passionate about motor sport. To save money, Jeff rode to work on an old bicycle and also used it to go to Amsterdam on holiday. That trip opened his eyes and he decided to see the world by bike. Jeff didn’t want a normal touring bike and he knew he wanted to build one himself. He built a penny farthing and travelled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. Despite some challenges, Jeff says he would do it all again if he could afford it.

I work at a university in the US. My team and I are learning more about water birds, especially one called the American black duck. We have started using a new piece of equipment called a night-vision scope, which allows us to see the ducks in the dark. We are worried about black ducks because their numbers have fallen hugely. We don’t know whether there’s enough food on the east coast for these animals. We have lots of information about their daytime activities, but nothing about what they do at night, because we simply haven’t had the equipment. But this new ‘scope’ will produce really clear pictures, even on moonless nights, so we’ll be able to find out more and make better decisions about looking after the area where they live based on what we learn. It is hard work. There are four of us, each working six hours daily. We have studied ducks in different locations, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and make notes on every duck I see. The weather hasn’t helped – some nights are mild, but more often it’s wet. Oh, and it’s so quiet I’ve needed lots of coffee to stop me falling asleep! We’ve only missed one working day so far, because the snow was too deep even for our special snow vehicles. Still I like the challenge of it, especially compared to what the summer will bring – hours in a laboratory, where we’ll look at our results together. It’ll be hard to be stuck inside – but it’s essential to do this. And I wouldn’t change it for anything!

**
I work as a chocolate taster. My job is to make sure that customers get perfect bars of high-quality chocolate. I receive samples of chocolate from the factory and taste them to see if they are perfect. I also taste the raw materials that are used to make chocolate. I spend days choosing the most suitable ones to go into the chocolate. I have a kitchen where I can test and taste products I make. It’s wonderful to have a private space where I can go off to during the day. Sometimes I am at the food lab and others I’m out of the country buying raw materials. But I love my job, even though it can be difficult.

Have you ever wondered what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a centre that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it includes many skills, such as juggling, throwing and catching things, trapeze, which involves flying through the air, and other fun activities. On the year-long course, students gradually increase the amount of risk they take in each class and parents come along to certain classes to watch progress.
To be successful in the circus, you must keep practising and be fit. You also need to have imagination and never stop improving your skills. Being fit is really important for circus artists, like athletes, who train daily to keep strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination and never stop improving skills.
The course also covers business planning. Many previous students set up businesses all over the world, and are happy to share their experiences. However, Sophia warns, it's not a profession for making money. "The work typically means not having a regular salary. It's also competitive - but great fun!"

**
Mariam Hobson is a professional singer who sings in the background to support the lead singer. She has to be better than the lead singer. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry.
Mariam loves her job because she gets to sing different types of music. Sometimes she sings classical, jazz, hiphop or rock. Other times she sings funny little tunes for the radio or advertisements. Sometimes she is surprised by what she is asked to sing. Once she was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But Mariam never argues, she just gets on with the job.
To be successful in her job, Mariam needs to have excellent musical abilities and the ability to learn quickly. There is often no printed music to refer to. Sometimes there are a lot of people singing different tunes and an orchestra as well. Mariam is terrified when she knows that if she gets something wrong, she will have to record everything again.
Mariam also loves to help song-writers. She helps them to understand which musical range suits the female voice best. By listening to her perform their song, they can work out for themselves how to improve it.

**
Julie Deane started a business selling satchels, which are traditional bags used by schoolchildren. Her business is successful, and her satchels are sold in famous shops and worn by celebrities. Before starting her business, Julie made a list of different businesses she could choose from. She decided to sell satchels because there was a demand for them. She involved her family in her business, and the design of the satchels came from children’s story books. To create interest in her business, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers and hoped they would write about them. They did write, and interest has continued to grow. Now, Julie loves seeing celebrities wearing her satchels. She uses the internet community for ideas for original styles, and she keeps her products new and exciting. There was a time when a company copied Julie’s design, but she has since made sure that she is confident in her production team. Visitors comment on the positive feeling in her offices, and there is a new factory.

**
When Vicky Harmiston was young, her parents gave her and her brother Jamie the freedom to do what they wanted in their free time. Vicky liked to do many different sports. She was a good swimmer and the coach at the swimming club thought she might be good enough to become a champion. But the club was far from her home so it was difficult for her to fit in the training around her schoolwork. When they were teenagers, Jamie loved cycling and he bought himself a special track racing bike and started taking part in competitions. Vicky thought it looked very exciting and decided to try it for herself. She says that was the best decision she ever made. Soon she was cycling every day and doing really well. The track was near her school, which meant it was no problem for her to attend training sessions after school every day. Vicky went on to have a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. Then, when she was 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky told me: ‘For years I’d loved winning competitions but I began to get a bit tired of the whole thing – and when the excitement stops, there’s no point. Luckily, I went on to have a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to learn to believe in themselves and their own abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it gets young people together so they’re part of a wider group.’

Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson was born in Ireland. Her parents weren’t musicians, but there was always music in the house. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother to play. The first time Ana sang in front of an audience was at school. She was very nervous, so her teacher had to help her. The teacher suggested that Ana join the school theatre club. After attending the club for a while, she sang with 50 other students at an end-of-term concert. A year later, her brother asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, and it was a big success. She also wrote another song called Something to Say about how annoyed she felt. She posted this song online and it became a huge success. One of Ana’s favourite songs is Decision, which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while.

**
Last year, I went on a trip to Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He’s a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. I had dreamt of visiting the area ever since I saw it on TV as a child. So I asked Harry if I could go too – until he finally agreed. There were storms in the area we were going to, but luckily the weather was calm. We joined the group and set off in small boats. The coast was full of beautiful beaches and rock pools. We stopped for hours to explore the rock pools and saw amazing fish. We also made camp fires and shared meals. When it was time to leave, I was sad. But I knew I had to go back to my family and friends. I was also looking forward to telling everyone about our adventures.

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, like his father before him. I went to watch many of his games when I was a kid. It was fun to see my dad play, but I didn’t love the sport. I loved telling my friends about my dad’s games, but I used to read books instead of watching. In secondary school, I was tall and my sports teacher asked me if I’d be interested in training with the basketball team. I enjoyed the session, but I thought I’d need to develop my skills before I took part in a real match. It took me a while to agree, but a few weeks later, I found myself playing against a team from another school. My parents came to watch, but it made me more nervous. But it was OK in the end. I practised every day and did really well. I joined an adult team before I moved abroad to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was fantastic to work with him. However, I can’t say I enjoyed my first experience of living far from my parents. At home, I’d never been able to spend much time with my friends due to all the training, so that wasn’t such a change for me. I got used to my new life in the end, though, and my English improved quickly too! I turned professional at the age of eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I was taller than most players in the professional league, but I was much too light for my height, so had to get that right first. I joined a team and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying tourism in college, but I needed to find a part-time job because my course was expensive. I decided to become a weekend tour guide in my city, Chicago. I took visitors around the city and I discovered that I enjoyed giving tours. I felt like I was seeing the city in a new way every time. After finishing my studies, I decided to go into tour guiding full-time. To become a full-time tour guide, I had to learn a lot of things. I had to know a lot about the city, including its history and architecture. I also had to be able to answer many questions about the city. After completing my training, I became a licensed tour guide. Being a tour guide is not just about knowing facts. You also need to be able to be entertaining and tell interesting stories. You need to be able to react to changing situations and make sure that your visitors are happy. If they are not happy, they could post a negative review online. That's why making tours fun and stress-free is essential.

**
My name is Ella. I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand with my sister Josie. We went to help as volunteers at an elephant sanctuary. It was our first time doing something like that. We collected the elephants' food and washed them in the river. We also led the elephants on foot into the forest. The evenings were fun. We talked and played games. Now that we're back in the UK, Josie doesn't often talk about Thailand. But if anyone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it.

My name is Gina D’Costa and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers to people who buy them for friends, their homes, or other reasons. Sometimes we provide flowers for hotels and offices, and we also take part in photo sessions for businesses. Once I decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was proud of the job we’d done.
My day starts early, at 4 a.m., when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. It’s usually cold and dark at that time, but I don’t mind. The market is full of beautiful flowers. I like to choose flowers that are perfect for the customer’s order. Sometimes it’s not easy to find the right flowers, but I try to get the best possible price.
Back at the shop, I look at customer orders and set up vases with the flowers I’ve bought. Then I create bunches of flowers and work out how much the order will cost. Customers are often surprised by how expensive their orders are. Sometimes I have to ask them to think again about what they’d like. But I like thinking about how I can put together the nicest possible flowers for the amount of money someone wants to spend. That’s what you have to do when you’re selling things. I wouldn’t want any other job.

My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films I want to see, and there are also lots of films for kids at the weekends. It’s close to where I live, but a year ago, I realized something was missing – the experience of discussing a film in detail with a group of people after watching it with them. So, together with two friends, I started a film club. We decided that we didn’t want to hire a cinema to show the films. Instead, we choose a different location in the city each month. For example, we rented an old factory to show a film that was set in Antarctica. It was very cold, and this created the perfect atmosphere for the film, which was brilliant! Some places we use are even free, as the owners make money by selling snacks during the film. We’re happy to make enough to cover our costs – we’re not trying to make a profit. Each time we show a film, everything is a bit easier for us. We also know how many tickets we’ve sold because everything’s online. There’s still always plenty to do, but when people of all ages come up at the end to say what a great experience they’ve had, it’s wonderful. We’ve started a blog, too, because we know that most people now go online for information about films, rather than read reviews in local papers. We’ve also tried putting up a few posters in cafés. Nothing’s as successful as word of mouth, though – people recommending us to their friends.

Taking photographs was always my favorite activity when I was a child. When I was 15, I knew that if I wanted to take my hobby to the next level, I had to do something special. So I decided to start a personal project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year of my life. Many other young photographers had done the same thing before me, but it seemed like a really great idea to me. After a few weeks, I put my photos on a website for young photographers. I was surprised to find that there were others who liked the way I saw and photographed things. I was also enjoying photographing a wide range of subjects. Someone suggested that if my photographs all had a common topic or idea to connect them, my project would be even better. So I began to concentrate more on taking photos of nature scenes, especially of birds and the sky. A lot of them were black and white photographs, which was different to what many other young photographers were doing. Sometimes I had doubts about my project, and I almost gave up several times. But I trusted my own feelings and became more confident about my photographic style and choices. One day I showed my project to my art teacher at school. She told me about a national photography competition for people my age. So I entered some of my photos, just for fun. I’ll never forget the moment when the judges told me that I had won first prize. It was the first time I realised that maybe my photography really was good, and that I might actually be able to work as a professional photographer. Now I have my own photography studio and I’ve never regretted my career choice.

**
Last year, I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) because I wanted to learn new skills and have new experiences. In the NYC, you can do many different activities to challenge yourself and learn new things. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, run by adult volunteers called 'leaders'. When you complete each level, you get a certificate.
When I first joined, my leader suggested that my first challenge should be helping to organise activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was a bit nervous at first, but I decided to take up the challenge. Soon, I was spending all my free time at the children’s club. I made a lot of new friends and I also learned new skills, such as public speaking and communication.
Now I’m at the children’s club for about four hours a week. I always really look forward to going. I’ve also decided that when I finish school, I want to go to college to become a youth worker. I never thought about my future job before, but the idea of youth work has entered my mind. This has been my favourite part of the NYC so far and I’ve improved my own communication skills while at the same time helping others.

**
I was born in Denver, USA. When I was eight years old, my Dad took me to a resort in the mountains, about two hours from Denver. The hill was very steep, so my dad had to do a lot of persuading to get me on a board. I was so young, I hadn’t even thought of asking him if I could start snowboarding, but he was already into it and wanted me to love it too. I managed to do well. After this experience, I started to love snowboarding and improve my ability. I started competing aged ten. I enjoy taking part in competitions and winning too. I also get to spend lots of time with my friends. It’s the best way of dealing with not being able to do what I love so much. I have to think carefully about my future. Snowboarding is such a huge part of my life now, but I also feel it’s important to have something else I can do, just in case I don’t succeed as a professional snowboarder or if I get injured.

**
When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had. I didn't plan ahead, like what I wanted to do when I left school. One day, my best friend got a new phone and I thought I should have one too. My parents said I could only have it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save as much as I could. It was a valuable lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn't really enjoy it. My parents suggested starting my own little business instead. I asked my mum if I could have a go at making necklaces. It was easy to learn. I sold my first items of jewellery to my friends and family. They were delighted with them, but I still needed convincing that they looked good enough to be popular with the public. There was only one way to find out, so I rented a market stall with my mum. Lots of people bought my things. Soon we were receiving calls from all over the country from people looking to buy more. It was a big success. Since then, I've made thousands of pounds through my business, mostly online. It's been such a lot of fun so far.

When Janine Stuart was young, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia which became popular. The book is based on Janine’s life. In one interview, Janine said that because of her family’s moving around a lot, she became good at making new friends. She also understood what it was like to be the only new student in a class. The book has funny parts about Amelia’s home life, particularly her relationship with her older brother. Janine started her novel one summer when she was feeling bored at home. She had a dream of becoming a published author, and she wrote a lot. When Janine finished her novel, people were excited to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was on sale in bookshops. The book has a lot of happy teenagers on the cover, but the people in the story actually face some difficult challenges. This is what makes the book interesting. Janine is still getting used to being famous. She says that she would like to give advice to other young writers, but they have to find what works for them.

**
My name is Tom. I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. My dad was invited to be the manager of the castle. He works for an organisation that looks after historical buildings. It was a long time before the rest of us agreed Dad should take the job. But once we moved, we quickly got used to island life. The castle isn’t very beautiful, but our apartment is comfortable. The island feels very sociable in the summer, and there are often parties on the beach. In the winter, there are not as many people living on the island. But the adults all support each other and help with repairs on the island. The biggest change for me was travelling by boat every day. I was looking forward to going on stormy days, but the ferries don’t run then. And I’ve discovered that if I miss the bus to the harbour after school, I also miss the last ferry home. So I always tell my schoolmates to hurry up when they come home to stay with me.

I live in a beautiful house in Scotland, surrounded by nature. I love animals and birds, and I started a new hobby called birdwatching six years ago. I went to the mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw lots of birds. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to tell the difference between species and how to find the best places to see them. It was amazing, and I joined a local club for young birdwatchers. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I’m close to achieving that. I’ve been to many places to see birds, including Egypt and South America. I also posted a video online about my challenge, and many people enjoyed it. I might even do another one next year. I’m lucky to live in the countryside, and I think everyone should connect with nature, regardless of their age or financial resources.

I started playing football when I was 7. I would rush home from school to play with other boys and girls. I loved it, and I was good at it. But my family thought that I would drop out like I had with other hobbies. But it never happened. I was already dreaming of playing football professionally when I was older. And the opportunity came sooner than I’d hoped. I played in local tournaments, and one of the referees noticed that I was a promising player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she asked me to join her club. I started regular training with a big club as a young 13-year-old. I improved enormously. But people still weren’t sure I’d ever be a star player, which made me feel a bit upset. But my coach encouraged me to just be myself, and believe in myself. He even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches, much earlier than I’d expected. I ran so hard in that match, I didn’t want the other players to blame me for losing. And I got the winning goal. Since then, I’ve scored lots more winning goals. And next month, my coach and I are running a football tournament in my area. The aim is to get teenagers interested in football, and to have a chance to chat to other players in my club.
